Conduct the control assessments as planned, ensuring that all relevant controls are assessed
Document the results of the control assessments, including any identified weaknesses or deficiencies
Develop and implement a plan to address any identified weaknesses or deficiencies in the security controls
Monitor the effectiveness of the security controls on an ongoing basis and update the control assessment plan as necessary
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented control assessment plan, that control assessments are conducted regularly and whenever significant changes occur, and that the organization takes action to address any identified weaknesses or deficiencies.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods:

title: Information Exchange
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that information exchange between systems is protected and controlled. This is important for security and compliance because it helps prevent unauthorized access and data breaches, and ensures that the organization's information systems are interconnected in a secure manner.
description: This control requires organizations to authorize, monitor, and control system connections and information exchanges between different systems. It also requires organizations to document these system interconnections in a formal agreement.
implementation_guidance: Identify all system interconnections and information exchanges that occur within your organization
Develop and implement a policy that outlines how system interconnections should be authorized, monitored, and controlled
Document each system interconnection in a formal agreement that includes details such as the interface characteristics, security requirements, and the nature of the information communicated
Regularly review and update the system interconnection agreements as necessary
Monitor the system interconnections to ensure they are functioning as intended and in accordance with the agreement
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all system interconnections, developed and implemented a policy for managing these interconnections, documented each interconnection in a formal agreement, and is actively monitoring the system interconnections.

title: Security Certification
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the system's security controls are effective and operating as intended. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities and risks.
description: This control requires the organization to conduct a thorough review of the security controls in the system to determine the extent to which the controls are implemented correctly, operating as intended, and producing the desired outcome with respect to meeting the security requirements for the system.
implementation_guidance: Develop a security certification plan that outlines the scope, approach, resources, and schedule of the certification process
Conduct a comprehensive assessment of the system's security controls to verify their effectiveness
Document the findings of the assessment in a security certification report
Provide the security certification report to the authorizing official to inform the security authorization decision
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a well-documented security certification plan and has conducted a thorough assessment of the system's security controls. They will also look for a comprehensive security certification report that details the findings of the assessment.
assessment_methods: Compliance will be verified through a combination of methods. The "examine" method will involve reviewing the security certification plan and report. The "interview" method will involve discussions with personnel responsible for the security certification process. The "test" method may involve a review of the procedures used to assess the effectiveness of the system's security controls.

title: Plan of Action and Milestones
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have a systematic approach to identify, prioritize, and monitor the progress of resolving weaknesses in their information systems and programs. This is crucial for maintaining the security and compliance of the system.
description: This control requires organizations to develop and implement a Plan of Action and Milestones (POA&M) that outlines how they will address weaknesses or deficiencies in security controls. The POA&M should be updated regularly and include information on resources required to address each issue, scheduled completion dates, and key milestones.
implementation_guidance: Identify weaknesses or deficiencies in security controls through assessments, audits, or other means
Prioritize identified weaknesses based on their potential impact on the system and the organization
Develop a POA&M that includes a detailed plan for addressing each weakness. This should include the resources required, scheduled completion dates, and key milestones
Implement the POA&M, ensuring that all necessary resources are allocated and that progress is tracked regularly
Update the POA&M as necessary, based on changes in the system, the organization, or the threat landscape
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a comprehensive POA&M in place, that it is being implemented effectively, and that it is updated regularly. They will also look for evidence that the organization is prioritizing weaknesses appropriately and allocating resources effectively.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through examination of the POA&M and related documentation, interviews with personnel responsible for implementing the POA&M, and testing to verify that the actions outlined in the POA&M are being carried out effectively.

title: Authorization
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that systems are authorized to operate by a senior official (or designated representative) based on the implementation of an agreed-upon set of security controls. This is important for security and compliance as it ensures that the system's security controls meet the organization's risk tolerance before it is allowed to operate.
description: This control requires that the organization authorizes the information system for processing before operations and periodically thereafter. The authorization decision is to be informed by the security assessment process, risk management strategy, and continuous monitoring program.
implementation_guidance: Identify a senior official or designated representative responsible for authorizing the system to operate
Conduct a comprehensive security assessment to evaluate the effectiveness of the implemented security controls
Document the security assessment results and any identified vulnerabilities in the System Security Plan (SSP)
Based on the security assessment results, the risk management strategy, and the continuous monitoring program, make an informed decision whether to authorize the system to operate
Document the authorization decision in a formal Authorization Decision Document
Review and update the authorization periodically or whenever significant changes are made to the system or its environment
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the system has been formally authorized to operate by a senior official or designated representative. They will also verify that the authorization decision was informed by a comprehensive security assessment, the organization's risk management strategy, and its continuous monitoring program.

title: Continuous Monitoring
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations are consistently monitoring and updating their security controls to maintain an acceptable level of risk. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to identify and address vulnerabilities in a timely manner, thereby reducing the potential for security breaches.
description: This control requires organizations to establish a continuous monitoring program that includes: a defined strategy and process, senior management involvement, integration with other organizational risk management processes, and providing ongoing updates to the security plan, security assessment report, and plan of action and milestones.
implementation_guidance: Develop a continuous monitoring strategy that outlines the frequency and nature of monitoring activities, considering the system's risk level and other factors
Establish a process for continuous monitoring that includes regular security control assessments, status reporting, and response actions
Ensure senior management is involved in the continuous monitoring process, providing necessary resources and support
Integrate the continuous monitoring process with other organizational risk management processes to ensure a holistic approach to risk management
Regularly update the System Security Plan (SSP), security assessment report, and plan of action and milestones based on the findings from the continuous monitoring process
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence of a well-defined and implemented continuous monitoring program. This includes a documented strategy, regular security control assessments, status reports, and updated security documents.

title: Penetration Testing
purpose: The purpose of this control is to identify vulnerabilities in an information system that could be exploited by adversaries. It provides a method for validating the effectiveness of security controls and revealing potential weaknesses in the system.
description: This control requires organizations to conduct penetration testing on an information system at least annually, or whenever significant changes occur in the system. The testing should simulate a malicious attack to identify vulnerabilities and evaluate the system's ability to resist and respond to such attacks.
implementation_guidance: Plan the Penetration Test:** Define the scope, objectives, and methods for the test. Identify the systems, networks, and applications to be tested
Assemble the Penetration Testing Team:** This could be an internal team or an external third-party. Ensure the team has the necessary skills and knowledge
Conduct the Penetration Test:** The team should simulate a malicious attack on the system, using various techniques to identify vulnerabilities
Analyze and Document the Results:** Identify and document vulnerabilities, the potential impact of exploitation, and recommended remediation actions
Remediate Identified Vulnerabilities:** Address the vulnerabilities identified in the penetration test. This could involve patching software, changing configurations, or implementing new controls
Repeat the Test:** After remediation actions have been taken, repeat the test to verify that the vulnerabilities have been effectively addressed
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that penetration testing has been conducted at least annually or when significant changes occur. They will also look for documentation of the test results and remediation actions.

title: Internal System Connections
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization authorizes, monitors, and controls internal system connections to maintain the integrity and security of the system. It helps prevent unauthorized access and data breaches.
description: This control requires the organization to authorize, monitor, and control all connections from the information system to other systems within the organization. It also requires the organization to document these connections in the system security plan.
implementation_guidance: Identify all internal system connections, including those to other systems within the organization
Establish a process for authorizing new internal system connections. This process should include a review of the security implications of the connection
Monitor all internal system connections on an ongoing basis to detect any unauthorized changes or connections
Establish a process for responding to unauthorized changes or connections. This process should include steps for investigating and resolving security incidents
Document all internal system connections, including the authorization process, monitoring process, and incident response process, in the system security plan
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all internal system connections, established processes for authorizing and monitoring these connections, and documented these processes in the system security plan. They will also look for evidence that the organization is effectively implementing these processes.

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to establish and maintain policies and procedures for managing the configuration of the organization's information system. This is important for security and compliance as it ensures that the system operates as intended and reduces the risk of unauthorized changes that could lead to vulnerabilities.
description: This control requires the organization to develop, document, and disseminate policies and procedures for managing the configuration of its information system. It also requires the organization to review and update these policies and procedures regularly.
implementation_guidance: Develop a policy that outlines the organization's approach to configuration management. This should include roles and responsibilities, scope, and objectives

Develop procedures that detail how the policy will be implemented. This should include steps for identifying configuration items, establishing baselines, authorizing changes, and monitoring the configuration
Disseminate the policy and procedures to all relevant personnel. This could be done through training, newsletters, or intranet posts
Review and update the policy and procedures at least annually, or whenever significant changes occur in the organization or its information system
Maintain records of policy and procedure reviews and updates
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy and procedures for configuration management, that these have been disseminated to relevant personnel, and that they are reviewed and updated regularly.

title: Baseline Configuration
purpose: The purpose of this control is to establish and maintain a baseline configuration of the information system. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to ensure that systems are configured in a secure manner and any changes to the configuration are properly managed and documented.
description: This control requires the organization to develop, document, and maintain a current baseline configuration of the information system. The organization must also review and update the baseline configuration as an integral part of the system development life cycle.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document the baseline configuration of the information system, including hardware, software, and firmware components
Establish a process for managing changes to the baseline configuration. This should include a formal approval process for proposed changes and a method for tracking all changes
Regularly review and update the baseline configuration as necessary. This should be done as part of the system development life cycle and should also include a review of the change management process
Ensure that the baseline configuration is securely stored and protected from unauthorized access or modification
Train relevant personnel on the process for managing changes to the baseline configuration
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented baseline configuration of the information system and a process for managing changes to this configuration. They will also check that the baseline configuration is regularly reviewed and updated, and that it is securely stored and protected from unauthorized access.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods. The "examine" method can be used to review the documented baseline configuration and change management process. The "interview" method can be used to verify that relevant personnel are aware of and understand the process. The "test" method can be used to verify that the process is being followed and that the baseline configuration is securely stored and protected.

title: Configuration Change Control
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that changes to the system configuration are properly managed and controlled. This is important for security and compliance because unauthorized or poorly managed changes can lead to vulnerabilities or system instability.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and enforce security configurations for information technology products employed within the system. It also requires the organization to track, review, approve, and audit changes to the system and its components.
implementation_guidance: Establish a Configuration Control Board (CCB) or similar entity to oversee and approve changes to the system configuration
Develop a formal process for proposing, reviewing, approving, and implementing changes to the system configuration
Document all proposed changes, including a description of the change, the reason for the change, and the potential impact on the system
Review and approve or deny proposed changes based on their potential impact on the system and its security
Implement approved changes in a controlled manner, including testing and validation to ensure the change does not adversely affect the system
Audit changes to ensure they were implemented as approved and did not adversely affect the system
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a formal process for managing changes to the system configuration, that this process is being followed, and that changes are being audited to ensure they are implemented as approved.

title: Impact Analyses
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that changes to the system do not inadvertently introduce vulnerabilities or disrupt operations. It helps to maintain the integrity, security, and reliability of the system.
description: This control requires organizations to analyze the security impacts of changes prior to implementation. It involves conducting thorough impact analyses to understand the potential consequences of changes to the system's configuration settings.
implementation_guidance: Establish a process:** Develop a formal process for conducting impact analyses before implementing any changes to the system
Define criteria:** Set clear criteria for what constitutes a significant change that would require an impact analysis

Conduct the analysis:** When a significant change is proposed, conduct an impact analysis to understand its potential effects on the system's security posture. This should include potential vulnerabilities that could be introduced and how the change could affect existing security controls
Document the results:** Record the results of the impact analysis, including any identified risks and proposed mitigation strategies
Review and approve:** Have the results reviewed and approved by appropriate personnel before implementing the change
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a formal process for conducting impact analyses, that this process is consistently followed, and that the results of these analyses are properly documented and reviewed.

title: Access Restrictions for Change
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized changes to the system configuration that could potentially compromise the security or integrity of the system. It ensures that only authorized personnel have the ability to make changes to the system.
description: This control requires organizations to define, document, approve, and enforce access restrictions for changes to the system. This includes changes to the system components, system configuration settings, and system-related information.
implementation_guidance: Define Access Restrictions:** Identify and define the access restrictions for making changes to the system. This should be based on roles and responsibilities within the organization
Document Access Restrictions:** Document the defined access restrictions in a formal policy or procedure
Approve Access Restrictions:** The access restrictions should be approved by the appropriate authority within the organization
Enforce Access Restrictions:** Implement the approved access restrictions using appropriate technical controls, such as access control lists or role-based access control mechanisms
Monitor and Review:** Regularly monitor and review the effectiveness of the access restrictions and make necessary adjustments as required
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has defined, documented, approved, and enforced access restrictions for changes to the system. They will also check that the organization regularly reviews and updates these access restrictions as necessary.

title: Configuration Settings
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization establishes and enforces the security configuration settings for information technology products employed within the system. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent unauthorized access, data breaches, and other security incidents.
description: This control requires the organization to establish, implement, and manage the security configuration settings for IT products used within the system. It also mandates the documentation, monitoring, and approval of deviations from established configuration settings.
implementation_guidance: Identify all IT products used within the system
Establish baseline security configuration settings for each IT product. These settings should align with industry best practices and regulatory requirements
Document the established configuration settings and the rationale for any deviations from the baseline settings
Implement the security configuration settings on all IT products
Regularly monitor and review the configuration settings to ensure they remain effective and relevant
Establish a process for approving and documenting deviations from the established configuration settings
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has established and implemented security configuration settings for all IT products. They will also check for documentation of these settings and any approved deviations.

title: Least Functionality
purpose: The purpose of this control is to minimize the potential attack surface and reduce the risk of unauthorized access to systems by limiting system functionality to the minimum necessary for business operations. This includes disabling unnecessary ports, protocols, services, and functions.
description: This control requires organizations to configure the system to provide only essential capabilities and to identify, document, and justify all instances of functionality deemed to be necessary for business operations.
implementation_guidance: Identify Essential Functions:** Start by identifying the essential functions that your system needs to perform its intended purpose
Configure System:** Configure the system to provide only these essential capabilities. This may involve disabling unnecessary services, protocols, ports, or functions
Document Justifications:** For each instance of functionality that is enabled, document a justification explaining why it is necessary for business operations
Review and Update:** Regularly review and update the system configuration to ensure it continues to provide only the minimum necessary functionality as the business needs evolve
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the system has been configured to provide only essential capabilities, and that all instances of functionality have been justified as necessary for business operations. They will also check that the system configuration is regularly reviewed and updated.

title: System Component Inventory
purpose: The purpose of this control is to maintain an inventory of all system components within an organization to ensure that each component is accounted for, properly configured, and updated. This is crucial for security and compliance as it helps in identifying unauthorized components and mitigating potential vulnerabilities.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and maintain an up-to-date inventory of all system components. The inventory should include information necessary to track, report, and correct security flaws and to define points of contact for the components.
implementation_guidance: Identify all system components including hardware, software, and network devices
Develop and document a comprehensive inventory of these components. The inventory should include details such as component type, version, location, point of contact, and security configuration
Implement a process to keep the inventory up-to-date. This should include procedures for adding new components, updating existing ones, and removing decommissioned components
Regularly review and verify the inventory for accuracy and completeness
Implement security measures to protect the inventory from unauthorized access and modification
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for a comprehensive and up-to-date system component inventory. They will also evaluate the procedures for maintaining the inventory and the security measures protecting it.

title: Configuration Management Plan
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has a structured and documented plan for managing changes to its information system. This is crucial for maintaining system security, as unplanned or uncontrolled changes can introduce vulnerabilities or disrupt system operations.
description: This control requires the organization to develop, document, and implement a Configuration Management (CM) plan. The plan should cover roles and responsibilities, configuration change control procedures, security impact analysis, and more.
implementation_guidance: Identify Key Stakeholders:** Identify individuals who will be responsible for developing, implementing, and maintaining the CM plan

Develop the CM Plan:** The plan should define the configuration items (CIs) to be managed, the procedures for managing changes to CIs, and the roles and responsibilities of individuals involved in CM processes
Implement the CM Plan:** Ensure that all relevant personnel are aware of the CM plan and their responsibilities under it. Implement the procedures defined in the plan for managing changes to CIs
Maintain the CM Plan:** Regularly review and update the CM plan to ensure it remains effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented CM plan, that the plan is being implemented effectively, and that it is regularly reviewed and updated. They will also look for evidence that changes to CIs are managed in accordance with the plan.

title: Software Usage Restrictions
purpose: The purpose of this control is to limit the risk of security vulnerabilities and potential attacks that can result from unauthorized software usage. It helps to ensure that only approved and necessary software is used within the system, reducing the attack surface and enhancing overall system security.
description: This control requires organizations to establish usage restrictions and supervision for software programs and software executed by users. It also mandates the documentation of software usage policies and enforcement procedures.
implementation_guidance: Establish Software Usage Policies:** Define and document policies that specify which software applications, operating systems, and utilities are authorized to be used within the system
Identify Unauthorized Software:** Use automated tools to scan systems regularly and identify any unauthorized software that is installed or being used
Implement Software Usage Restrictions:** Enforce software usage restrictions through technical controls such as application whitelisting and user privilege settings
Monitor and Supervise Software Usage:** Regularly monitor software usage and supervise users to ensure compliance with the established policies
Update and Review Policies:** Regularly review and update software usage policies to accommodate changes in the system or threat landscape
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that software usage policies are in place, that unauthorized software is being identified and removed, and that software usage is being monitored and supervised. They will also check that policies are regularly reviewed and updated.

title: User-installed Software
purpose: The purpose of this control is to limit the potential security vulnerabilities that can arise from unauthorized or uncontrolled software installations by users. It helps to maintain the integrity of system configurations and reduces the risk of malware or other harmful software being installed.
description: This control requires the organization to establish and enforce policies that restrict the installation of software by users. The policies should define authorized users, conditions for software installation, and procedures for obtaining necessary approvals.
implementation_guidance: Develop a policy that restricts the installation of software by users. The policy should clearly define who is authorized to install software and under what conditions
Establish procedures for users to request and obtain approval for software installation. This could include a formal request process and a review by IT or security personnel
Implement technical controls to enforce the policy, such as user permissions and software installation restrictions
Train users on the policy and procedures. Ensure they understand the risks associated with unauthorized software installation
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures as necessary, and retrain users as needed
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy and procedures in place to restrict user-installed software. They will also look for evidence that the policy is being enforced and that users are aware of and understand the policy.

title: Information Location
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization is aware of the physical and logical location of its information system components. This is important for security and compliance as it helps in risk management, incident response, and recovery procedures.
description: This control requires the organization to maintain an inventory of the physical and logical locations of all components of its information system. It also requires the organization to document the location of information system components that are mobile or can be relocated.
implementation_guidance: Inventory Creation:** Begin by creating an inventory of all components of the information system. This includes servers, workstations, networking equipment, and any other hardware or software components
Physical Location Identification:** Identify and document the physical location of each component. This could be a specific room, building, or even a geographic location for remote components
Logical Location Identification:** Identify and document the logical location of each component. This could include the network address, subnet, or any other logical identifiers
Mobile/Relocatable Component Documentation:** For components that are mobile or can be relocated, document their typical location and any potential alternate locations
Inventory Maintenance:** Regularly update the inventory to reflect any changes in the location of components
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a complete and accurate inventory of the physical and logical locations of all components of its information system. They will also check that the organization has procedures in place to keep this inventory up to date.

title: Data Action Mapping
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization maps the flow of information within the system and identifies the points where data can be exposed to unauthorized access or manipulation. This helps in identifying potential vulnerabilities and implementing appropriate security measures.
description: This control requires the organization to document the flow of data within the system, including inputs, outputs, and interfaces. The organization must also identify and document the actions that can be performed on the data at each point in the flow.
implementation_guidance: Identify Data Flow:** Identify and document all data inputs, outputs, and interfaces within the system
Map Data Actions:** Identify and document all actions that can be performed on the data at each point in the flow. This includes actions such as creation, access, modification, and deletion
Identify Vulnerabilities:** Use the data flow and action map to identify potential vulnerabilities, such as points where data can be accessed or modified without authorization
Implement Security Measures:** Implement appropriate security measures to protect the data at each point in the flow. This could include access controls, encryption, and monitoring
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has accurately mapped the flow of data within the system and identified all possible actions on the data. They will also look for evidence that the organization has identified potential vulnerabilities and implemented appropriate security measures.

title: Signed Components
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure the integrity and authenticity of the system components. It prevents unauthorized modifications and mitigates the risk of malicious code execution by verifying the digital signatures of system components.
description: This control requires that the organization employs mechanisms to verify the digital signatures of system components before installation or execution. It ensures that the components are signed using a recognized and trusted source.
implementation_guidance: Identify all system components that are to be signed. This could include software, firmware, and information system components
Establish a policy that requires all identified components to be signed using a recognized and trusted source
Implement mechanisms to verify the digital signatures of the components before installation or execution. This could be done using cryptographic tools or software
Ensure that the verification process is integrated into the system's configuration management and change control processes
Train relevant personnel on the policy and the process of verifying digital signatures
Regularly review and update the policy and verification process as necessary
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy for signing system components and that mechanisms are in place to verify these signatures. They will also check that the verification process is integrated into the system's configuration management and change control processes.

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to establish and maintain effective contingency planning policies and procedures. This is crucial for security and compliance as it ensures that organizations are prepared to respond effectively to incidents or disruptions, minimizing the impact on operations and data integrity.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and disseminate a contingency planning policy and procedures. The policy should define roles, responsibilities, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance. The procedures should facilitate the implementation of the policy and associated contingency planning controls.
implementation_guidance: Develop a contingency planning policy that outlines the organization's approach to manage and recover from disruptions. This should include roles, responsibilities, and coordination among different entities

Document procedures that provide detailed steps to implement the contingency planning policy. This should include steps for identifying potential disruptions, activating the contingency plan, and recovering operations
Disseminate the policy and procedures to all relevant parties within the organization
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain relevant and effective
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for a documented and disseminated contingency planning policy and procedures. They will evaluate whether the policy defines roles, responsibilities, and coordination, and whether the procedures facilitate the implementation of the policy and associated controls.

title: Contingency Plan
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have a comprehensive and effective plan in place to respond to and recover from events that disrupt normal operations. This is crucial for maintaining the security and integrity of the system and its data during and after an unexpected event.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, periodically update, and implement a contingency plan for their information system. The plan should address maintaining essential operations during a contingency, recovery of the system after the contingency, and reconstitution of the system to a fully operational state.
implementation_guidance: Identify Essential Functions:** Identify the essential functions of the information system and the resources needed to maintain them during and after a contingency

Develop Contingency Plan:** Develop a contingency plan that outlines the procedures to be followed in the event of a system disruption or failure. The plan should include roles and responsibilities, communication strategies, and recovery procedures
Document the Plan:** Document the contingency plan in a formal, written document. The plan should be easily accessible and understandable to those who will need to implement it
Train Personnel:** Train relevant personnel on their roles and responsibilities under the contingency plan. This should include regular drills or exercises to test the plan's effectiveness

Review and Update the Plan:** Regularly review and update the contingency plan to ensure it remains relevant and effective. This should be done at least annually, or whenever significant changes are made to the information system
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for a documented contingency plan that is comprehensive, up-to-date, and effectively implemented. They will also look for evidence that personnel are trained on the plan and that it is regularly tested and updated.

title: Contingency Training
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that personnel are adequately trained to execute contingency plans in the event of a system disruption or failure. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to minimize the impact of such events on the organization's operations, assets, and individuals.
description: This control requires organizations to provide appropriate training to information system users consistent with assigned roles and responsibilities, about the contingency plans and procedures. The training should be given before the contingency plans are needed and should be refreshed periodically.
implementation_guidance: Identify the personnel who have roles in the execution of contingency plans
Develop a training program that covers the contingency plans and procedures, tailored to the roles and responsibilities of the identified personnel
Conduct the training sessions, ensuring that all identified personnel participate
Document the training provided, including the content, dates, and attendees
Review and update the training program periodically, or whenever significant changes are made to the contingency plans
Repeat the training sessions at regular intervals, or whenever new personnel are assigned roles in the contingency plans
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a contingency training program in place, that the training is tailored to the roles and responsibilities of the personnel, and that the training is conducted regularly and updated as necessary.

title: Contingency Plan Testing
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization's contingency plan is effective and capable of restoring system operations in the event of a disruption or failure. This is important for security and compliance as it minimizes the potential impact of system disruptions and ensures continuity of operations.
description: This control requires organizations to test their contingency plans for their information systems at least annually to verify the plan's effectiveness and to train personnel in executing the plan. The organization should also document the results of the contingency plan test.
implementation_guidance: Develop a comprehensive contingency plan that includes details on roles, responsibilities, and procedures to restore the system after a disruption or failure
Schedule and conduct contingency plan tests at least annually. The test can be a full-scale exercise or a table-top review, depending on the system's risk level and the organization's resources
Involve relevant personnel in the test to ensure they are familiar with their roles and responsibilities in the event of a system disruption
Document the results of the test, including any issues identified and corrective actions taken
Review and update the contingency plan based on the test results and any changes in the organization's operations or system environment
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a contingency plan in place, that the plan has been tested at least annually, and that the test results have been documented. They will also look for evidence that the plan is updated based on the test results and changes in the system environment.

title: Alternate Storage Site
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has a designated alternate storage site for its critical information and system components. This is important for security and compliance as it allows the organization to maintain its operations and recover quickly in case of a disaster or system failure.
description: This control requires the organization to identify an alternate storage site and ensure that this site, along with the necessary equipment, is available to store backups of information system data, software, and documentation. The site should be sufficiently distant to avoid being impacted by the same disaster.
implementation_guidance: Identify critical system components, data, and documentation that need to be backed up
Determine an appropriate alternate storage site that is geographically distant from the primary site to avoid being affected by the same disaster
Ensure that the alternate site has the necessary equipment and capacity to store the backups
Establish procedures for transporting backups to the alternate site and retrieving them when needed
Regularly test the effectiveness of the alternate storage site and update the contingency plan as necessary
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that an alternate storage site has been identified and is available for use. They will also check that the site has the necessary equipment and capacity, and that procedures are in place for transporting and retrieving backups.

title: Alternate Processing Site
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization has a designated alternate processing site to perform mission-critical functions in the event of a disruption or failure at the primary site. This is crucial for maintaining business continuity and minimizing downtime during unforeseen events.
description: This control requires the organization to identify an alternate processing site, establish agreements for its use, and ensure that the site is prepared to take over operations as quickly and smoothly as possible in the event of a disruption at the primary site.
implementation_guidance: Identify an appropriate alternate processing site. This could be a secondary data center, a cloud service, or another suitable location
Establish formal agreements for the use of the alternate site. This could involve contracts with third-party service providers or inter-departmental agreements within the organization
Equip the alternate site with the necessary hardware, software, and telecommunications capabilities to perform the organization's mission-critical functions
Develop and implement procedures for switching operations to the alternate site quickly and smoothly in the event of a disruption
Regularly test the procedures for switching to the alternate site and update them as necessary based on the results of these tests
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified an appropriate alternate processing site, established agreements for its use, and developed and tested procedures for switching operations to this site.

title: Telecommunications Services
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has alternative telecommunications services or a failover plan to maintain critical operations in the event of a loss of primary telecommunications services. This is important for security and compliance as it ensures continuity of operations and minimizes the impact of service disruptions.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and maintain redundant telecommunications services to support the continuity of operations in the event of a failure of primary telecommunications services.
implementation_guidance: Identify Critical Operations:** Determine which operations are critical to the organization's mission and must continue even in the event of a telecommunications failure
Assess Current Telecommunications Services:** Evaluate the reliability and redundancy of the current telecommunications services supporting these critical operations
Develop Redundant Telecommunications Services:** If necessary, establish additional or alternative telecommunications services to ensure the continuity of critical operations
Document and Maintain:** Document the redundant telecommunications services in the System Security Plan (SSP) and maintain them to ensure they remain effective and up-to-date
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified critical operations, evaluated the reliability of current telecommunications services, established redundant services, and documented these in the SSP.

title: System Backup
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization can recover and restore systems in the event of a disruption, failure, or disaster. This is important for maintaining the continuity of operations, minimizing data loss, and ensuring the availability of critical information systems.
description: This control requires organizations to conduct regular system backups, protect backup information, and store backup copies off-site. The backup process should include user-level information and system-level information, as well as system documentation.
implementation_guidance: Identify critical system components and data that need to be backed up
Develop a backup schedule based on the importance of data and system components, and the acceptable risk of data loss
Implement backup procedures, ensuring that both user-level and system-level information is backed up
Protect backup information at storage locations to prevent unauthorized access, modification, or destruction
Store backup copies at a separate, secure off-site location to protect against data loss from disasters at the primary site
Regularly test backup procedures to ensure they are working correctly and that data can be restored from backups
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a regular backup schedule, that backups are protected and stored off-site, and that backup procedures have been tested. They will also look for documentation of the backup procedures and the results of backup tests.

title: System Recovery and Reconstitution
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization can recover and reconstitute the system to a known secure state after a disruption, compromise, or failure. This is crucial for maintaining business continuity, minimizing downtime, and protecting sensitive data.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and implement procedures to restore the system after a disruption or failure. It also necessitates the reconstitution of the system to a known secure state, ensuring that system functionality and security are not compromised.
implementation_guidance: Develop a comprehensive system recovery and reconstitution plan. This should include procedures for restoring the system after a disruption, compromise, or failure
Identify and prioritize critical system components and data for recovery
Establish a secure backup strategy for all critical system components and data
Regularly test and update the recovery and reconstitution procedures to ensure they are effective and up-to-date
Train relevant personnel on the execution of the recovery and reconstitution procedures
Document all recovery and reconstitution activities for audit and review purposes
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a comprehensive system recovery and reconstitution plan in place. They will also verify that the plan is regularly tested and updated, and that personnel are trained on the procedures.

title: Contingency Plan Update
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization's contingency plan remains current and effective in the face of changing business needs, threats, and technologies. This is crucial for maintaining operational continuity and minimizing potential damage in the event of a disaster or system failure.
description: This control requires organizations to review and update their contingency plans at least annually or whenever there are significant changes to the system, environment, or operational requirements. The updated plan must be communicated to key personnel and relevant stakeholders.
implementation_guidance: Establish a schedule for regular contingency plan reviews, at least annually
Define criteria for triggering an unscheduled review, such as significant system updates, changes in operational requirements, or new threat intelligence

During each review, assess the plan's effectiveness in the current operational and threat environment. Consider changes in system architecture, new technologies, updated business needs, and evolving threats
Update the contingency plan based on the review findings. This may include changes to recovery strategies, personnel responsibilities, or communication procedures
Communicate the updated plan to all relevant personnel and stakeholders. Ensure they understand their roles and responsibilities in the event of a contingency
Document the review and update process, including the date of each review, the findings, the updates made, and the communication process
assessment_objectives: Assessors will verify that the organization has a process in place for regular contingency plan reviews and updates. They will check that the plan is updated at least annually or whenever significant changes occur. They will also confirm that the updated plan is communicated to relevant personnel and stakeholders.

title: Alternate Communications Protocols
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has alternate communication protocols in place to maintain critical operations in the event of a failure of primary communication systems. This is important for security and compliance as it ensures continuity of operations and minimizes downtime.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and implement alternate communication protocols, including providing personnel with the ability to communicate when primary communication systems are unavailable.
implementation_guidance: Identify critical communication systems and their associated protocols that are essential for the organization's operations
Develop alternate communication protocols for each identified critical communication system. These could include secondary communication channels, backup systems, or manual processes
Document the alternate communication protocols, including the conditions under which they should be used and the steps required to activate them

Train personnel on the use of alternate communication protocols. This should include regular drills to ensure personnel are familiar with the protocols and can implement them effectively in a real situation
Regularly review and update the alternate communication protocols to ensure they remain effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that alternate communication protocols have been established and implemented. They will also look for evidence that personnel have been trained on these protocols and that the protocols are regularly reviewed and updated.

title: Safe Mode
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the information system can be transitioned into a safe mode when needed. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to protect the system and its data during a security incident or when the system is at risk.
description: This control requires the organization to establish and implement procedures to transition the information system to a safe mode, where the system operations are minimized to critical functions only, in the event of a security incident or when the system is at risk.
implementation_guidance: Identify Critical Functions:** The first step is to identify the critical functions of the information system that must remain operational even in safe mode

Develop Safe Mode Procedures:** Develop procedures detailing how to transition the system to safe mode. This should include the conditions that trigger safe mode, the steps to transition to and from safe mode, and the operations that will continue in safe mode
Implement Safe Mode Procedures:** Implement the procedures into the system. This may involve configuring system settings or installing specific software
Test Safe Mode Procedures:** Regularly test the safe mode procedures to ensure they work as expected and make any necessary adjustments
Train Personnel:** Train relevant personnel on the safe mode procedures, including how to recognize when safe mode should be activated and the steps to transition to and from safe mode
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified critical functions, developed and implemented safe mode procedures, regularly tests these procedures, and has trained personnel on these procedures.

title: Alternative Security Mechanisms
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has alternative security mechanisms in place to maintain essential capabilities during a disruption, compromise, or failure of primary security controls. This is crucial for maintaining business continuity and minimizing potential damage to the organization's operations, assets, or individuals.
description: This control requires organizations to identify and implement alternative security mechanisms when primary security controls are unavailable or compromised. The alternative mechanisms should be capable of providing equivalent security measures to protect the organization's information systems and data.
implementation_guidance: Identify the primary security controls currently in place and understand their functions
Determine the essential capabilities that these controls provide
Identify potential scenarios where these primary controls may be unavailable or compromised
For each scenario, identify and evaluate potential alternative security mechanisms that can provide equivalent security measures
Implement the identified alternative security mechanisms and integrate them into the organization's contingency planning
Regularly review and update the alternative security mechanisms to ensure they remain effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified potential scenarios where primary security controls may fail, and that alternative security mechanisms have been implemented. They will also evaluate whether these alternative mechanisms can provide equivalent security measures.

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization has established and effectively implemented policies and procedures for identification and authentication. This is crucial for security and compliance as it helps prevent unauthorized access to system resources and data.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and disseminate policies and procedures that address purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, and management commitment related to system identification and authentication.
implementation_guidance: Develop a comprehensive policy that outlines the organization's approach to identification and authentication. This should include the purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, and management commitment
Document procedures that provide step-by-step instructions on how to implement the policy. This should include procedures for user registration, credential management, and authentication mechanisms
Disseminate the policy and procedures to all relevant personnel. This could be done through training sessions, email communications, or posting on the organization's intranet
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented policy and procedures for identification and authentication. They will also evaluate whether these documents have been disseminated to relevant personnel and are regularly reviewed and updated.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through the following methods:

title: Identification and Authentication (organizational Users)
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization uniquely identifies and authenticates organizational users (or processes acting on behalf of organizational users) before granting access to organizational systems. This is crucial for maintaining the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of the system and its data.
description: The control requires organizations to implement measures that uniquely identify and authenticate users or processes that are acting on behalf of users. This is typically achieved through the use of usernames and passwords, tokens, biometrics, or a combination of these methods.
implementation_guidance: Identify User Types:** Identify all types of users who need access to the system, including employees, contractors, and third-party users
Establish Identification Protocols:** Develop and implement protocols for uniquely identifying each user or process that requires access to the system
Implement Authentication Mechanisms:** Implement mechanisms for authenticating the identity of each user or process. This could include passwords, tokens, biometrics, or multi-factor authentication
Enforce Authentication:** Ensure that the system enforces the identification and authentication mechanisms before granting access
Monitor and Update:** Regularly monitor and update the identification and authentication mechanisms to ensure they remain effective against emerging threats
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented measures to uniquely identify and authenticate all users or processes that require access to the system. They will also check that these measures are enforced before access is granted.

title: Device Identification and Authentication
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization's information system uniquely identifies and authenticates devices before establishing a connection. This is crucial for security and compliance as it prevents unauthorized devices from gaining access to the system.
description: This control requires the information system to identify and authenticate devices before establishing a connection. This is typically achieved through the use of device identifiers and authenticators, such as digital certificates.
implementation_guidance: Identify Devices:** Start by identifying all devices that need to connect to your information system. This could include workstations, servers, network devices, and mobile devices

Establish Authentication Requirements:** Determine the level of authentication required for each device. This could be based on the device's role, the sensitivity of the data it accesses, or the risk associated with its potential compromise
Implement Device Identifiers:** Assign unique identifiers to each device. This could be a MAC address, a device serial number, or a digital certificate
Implement Device Authenticators:** Implement a method for authenticating the device's identifier. This could be a digital signature, a cryptographic key, or a password
Enforce Authentication:** Configure your information system to require device identification and authentication before establishing a connection
Monitor and Update:** Regularly monitor the effectiveness of your device identification and authentication controls and update them as necessary
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented device identification and authentication controls. They will want to see that each device has a unique identifier, that there is a method for authenticating these identifiers, and that the information system requires device identification and authentication before establishing a connection.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of examination, interview, and testing methods. For example, assessors might examine the organization's device identification and authentication policies, interview IT staff to understand how these policies are implemented, and test a sample of devices to verify that they are properly identified and authenticated before connecting to the information system.

title: Identifier Management
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization manages information system identifiers by receiving authorization from a designated organizational official. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent unauthorized access and misuse of system resources.
description: This control requires the organization to manage user identifiers by receiving authorization from a designated official. It also requires the organization to uniquely identify each user, process acting on behalf of users, or device.
implementation_guidance: Establish a policy for managing identifiers, including the process for assigning, changing, and revoking identifiers
Designate an official responsible for authorizing the assignment of user identifiers
Implement a system that uniquely identifies each user, process acting on behalf of users, or device
Ensure that the system is capable of managing identifiers, including the ability to revoke them when necessary
Regularly review and update the identifier management process to ensure it remains effective and secure
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy and process in place for managing identifiers. They will also look for evidence that the organization has a designated official responsible for authorizing the assignment of identifiers and that the system is capable of managing identifiers.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through several methods:

title: Authenticator Management
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure the management of information system authenticators, which are critical for maintaining the security of systems and data. Proper management of authenticators helps prevent unauthorized access and potential data breaches.
description: This control requires organizations to manage the lifecycle of authenticators, including their initial distribution, replacement, and revocation. It also requires organizations to protect authenticators against threats such as unauthorized disclosure and modification.
implementation_guidance: Establish Authenticator Management Policies and Procedures:** Define and document the policies and procedures for managing the lifecycle of authenticators
Initial Distribution:** Implement secure methods for distributing initial authenticators to users
Replacement:** Define a process for replacing lost, compromised, or damaged authenticators
Revocation:** Develop procedures for revoking authenticators, such as when a user leaves the organization or an authenticator is compromised
Protection of Authenticators:** Implement measures to protect authenticators from unauthorized disclosure and modification
Authenticator Feedback:** Provide feedback to users during authentication but ensure it does not reveal authentication information
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented policies and procedures for managing authenticators. They will also check that the organization has secure methods for distributing, replacing, and revoking authenticators, and that it protects authenticators from unauthorized disclosure and modification.

title: Authentication Feedback
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized individuals from gaining system access by guessing authentication information. It does this by limiting the feedback provided during the authentication process, which could otherwise aid unauthorized users in their attempts.
description: This control requires that the system obscures feedback of authentication information during the authentication process to protect the information from potential compromise. The feedback must be designed in a way that it does not provide information that would aid an unauthorized user in compromising the authentication mechanism.
implementation_guidance: Review the current authentication process and identify the feedback provided to users during this process
Analyze the identified feedback to determine if it could aid an unauthorized user in compromising the authentication mechanism

If such feedback is found, modify the authentication process to obscure or eliminate this feedback. This could involve replacing detailed error messages with generic ones, or not indicating which part of the authentication information was incorrect
Document the changes made and the reasons for them
Train users on the new authentication process and the reasons for the changes
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the system obscures or eliminates feedback during the authentication process that could aid an unauthorized user. They will also look for documentation of the changes made and the reasons for them, as well as evidence of user training.

title: Cryptographic Module Authentication
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the cryptographic modules used for system authentication processes are secure and reliable. It helps to prevent unauthorized access to system resources and data by ensuring that only authenticated modules are used in the system.
description: This control requires the organization to authenticate (or verify) the identity of the cryptographic modules used in the system. It ensures that the system uses only those cryptographic modules that meet the federal standards and have been tested and validated by the Cryptographic Module Validation Program (CMVP).
implementation_guidance: Identify all cryptographic modules used in the system for authentication processes
Verify that all identified cryptographic modules are compliant with federal standards (FIPS 140-2 or its successors)
Ensure that the cryptographic modules have been tested and validated by the CMVP
Implement a process to regularly review and update the cryptographic modules to ensure they remain compliant with the latest federal standards
Document the use and compliance status of all cryptographic modules in the System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will verify that the organization has identified all cryptographic modules used in the system and has authenticated them. They will also check that the cryptographic modules are compliant with federal standards and have been tested and validated by the CMVP.

title: Identification and Authentication (non-organizational Users)
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that non-organizational users (i.e., individuals who are not part of the organization but need access to its systems) are properly identified and authenticated before they can access the system. This is crucial for maintaining the security and integrity of the system.
description: This control requires the organization to implement identification and authentication processes for non-organizational users. These processes must be consistent with the applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance.
implementation_guidance: Define Policies:** Define clear policies and procedures for identification and authentication of non-organizational users
Implement Authentication Mechanisms:** Implement strong authentication mechanisms such as multi-factor authentication, digital certificates, or biometrics
User Agreements:** Establish user agreements for non-organizational users that outline the requirements for identification and authentication
Training:** Provide training to non-organizational users on the identification and authentication procedures
Monitor and Review:** Regularly monitor and review the identification and authentication processes to ensure they are effective and up-to-date
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented robust identification and authentication processes for non-organizational users. They will also check that these processes are regularly monitored and updated.

title: Service Identification and Authentication
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that services within an information system are authenticated before they can be accessed. This is crucial for security and compliance as it prevents unauthorized access to services, thereby protecting the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of the system.
description: This control requires the organization to identify and authenticate, or verify the identities of, all services and applications before they can be accessed. This is to ensure that only authorized services are allowed to operate within the system.
implementation_guidance: Identify Services:** Start by identifying all services and applications within your information system that require authentication

Establish Authentication Mechanisms:** Implement robust authentication mechanisms for each identified service. This could include mechanisms like passwords, digital certificates, or two-factor authentication
Configure Services:** Configure each service to require authentication before it can be accessed. Ensure that the authentication mechanism is properly integrated with the service
Test Authentication:** Test the authentication process to ensure it works as expected. This should include testing both successful and unsuccessful authentication attempts
Monitor and Review:** Regularly monitor and review the authentication process to ensure it remains effective. Update the authentication mechanisms as necessary to respond to evolving threats
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that all services within the system require authentication before they can be accessed. They will also look for evidence that the authentication mechanisms are robust and regularly reviewed and updated.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods:

title: Adaptive Authentication
purpose: The purpose of this control is to enhance security by dynamically adjusting the authentication requirements based on an assessed level of risk. This helps to prevent unauthorized access to systems and data, and increases the likelihood of detecting and responding to potential threats.
description: This control requires organizations to implement adaptive authentication mechanisms that react to anomalies or changes in behavior. These mechanisms adjust the strength of authentication based on the assessed level of risk, which can be determined by factors such as location, IP address, time of access, and behavior patterns.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document the risk factors that will trigger adaptive authentication, such as unusual login times, multiple failed login attempts, or access from new locations or devices

Implement an adaptive authentication system that can assess these risk factors and adjust the authentication requirements accordingly. This could involve multi-factor authentication, biometric verification, or security questions
Test the adaptive authentication system to ensure it is functioning correctly and adjusting authentication requirements based on the identified risk factors
Train users on the adaptive authentication system, explaining why it is necessary and how it works
Regularly review and update the risk factors and authentication requirements as necessary to respond to new threats or changes in the organization's risk profile
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented an adaptive authentication system that adjusts based on assessed risk. They will also look for documentation of the risk factors that trigger adaptive authentication and evidence that the system is functioning correctly.

title: Re-authentication
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the user or device still requires access to the system or application. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent unauthorized access and maintain the integrity of the system.
description: This control requires the system to enforce a re-authentication of users or devices under specific conditions, such as after a predetermined period of inactivity, or when a system or session risk level changes.
implementation_guidance: Define the conditions under which re-authentication will be required. These could include after a certain period of inactivity, when a system or session risk level changes, or when accessing sensitive data

Implement a mechanism that enforces re-authentication under the defined conditions. This could be a session timeout feature, a risk-based authentication system, or a multi-factor authentication system
Document the re-authentication process and conditions in the System Security Plan (SSP)
Train users on the re-authentication process and the importance of complying with it
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the system enforces re-authentication under the defined conditions. They will also look for documentation of the re-authentication process in the SSP, and evidence that users have been trained on the process.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified by examining the system to confirm that it enforces re-authentication under the defined conditions. The SSP can be examined to verify that the re-authentication process is documented. Interviews with users can be used to verify that they have been trained on the re-authentication process. Tests can be conducted to verify that the system enforces re-authentication as required.

title: Identity Proofing
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the identity of an individual or device is verified before an organizational information system account is created or a credential is issued. This is important for security and compliance as it prevents unauthorized access and potential misuse of system resources.
description: This control requires organizations to conduct identity proofing activities for individuals or devices before establishing an initial authenticator (like a password or token). The process must be repeated if there is a change in the individual's status or if the device is modified.
implementation_guidance: Develop and document an identity proofing process that aligns with the risk level of your system and the sensitivity of the data it processes
Implement the identity proofing process before issuing any initial authenticators to individuals or devices
Ensure the process includes verification of identity through reliable forms of identification, such as government-issued ID cards for individuals or manufacturer certificates for devices
Repeat the identity proofing process whenever there is a change in the individual's status or the device is modified
Regularly review and update the identity proofing process to ensure it remains effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented and implemented identity proofing process. They will also check that the process is followed before issuing initial authenticators and is repeated when necessary.

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have established and documented incident response policies and procedures. This is crucial for security and compliance as it helps organizations to effectively respond to security incidents, minimizing potential damage and recovery time.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, disseminate, and periodically review/update formal, documented procedures that facilitate the implementation of the incident response policy and associated incident response controls.
implementation_guidance: Develop an incident response policy that defines the organization's approach to handling security incidents. This should include roles and responsibilities, reporting hierarchy, and coordination mechanisms
Develop detailed incident response procedures aligned with the policy. These procedures should cover incident detection, reporting, assessment, response, and post-incident review
Disseminate the policy and procedures to all relevant personnel and stakeholders. This could be done through training, emails, intranet posts, or other communication channels

Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain relevant and effective. This should be done at least annually or whenever significant changes occur in the organization or its environment
