description: This control requires the organization to synchronize the system clocks of its information system with an authoritative time source. It also requires the organization to protect the time source from unauthorized modification and document the time synchronization process.
implementation_guidance: Identify an authoritative time source that the organization's systems will synchronize with. This could be a local server or an external time service
Configure all systems to synchronize their clocks with the identified authoritative time source. This can be done using protocols like Network Time Protocol (NTP) or Precision Time Protocol (PTP)
Implement measures to protect the time source from unauthorized modification. This could include network segmentation, firewalls, or access controls
Document the time synchronization process, including the authoritative time source, the synchronization protocol, and the measures taken to protect the time source
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization's systems are synchronizing their clocks with an authoritative time source. They will also look for measures to protect the time source from unauthorized modification and documentation of the time synchronization process.

title: Cross Domain Policy Enforcement
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization implements and enforces policies to manage information flow between different security domains. This is crucial to prevent unauthorized data transfer or leakage, and to maintain the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the system.
description: This control requires the organization to enforce cross-domain solutions, monitor and control communications at the system boundaries and external interfaces, and prevent unauthorized information transfer through shared resources.
implementation_guidance: Identify Security Domains:** Identify and categorize all security domains within your organization. Security domains could be different departments, networks, or systems with varying levels of sensitivity and access controls

Develop Cross-Domain Policies:** Develop policies that define the rules for information flow between these domains. The policies should consider the sensitivity of the data, the purpose of the transfer, and the security controls in place at the receiving domain
Implement Cross-Domain Solutions:** Implement solutions that enforce these policies. This could include firewalls, data loss prevention (DLP) tools, or secure gateways
Monitor and Control Communications:** Regularly monitor and control communications at the system boundaries and external interfaces to ensure compliance with the policies

Prevent Unauthorized Information Transfer:** Implement controls to prevent unauthorized information transfer through shared resources. This could include access controls, encryption, and segregation of networks
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified its security domains, developed and implemented cross-domain policies, and is actively monitoring and controlling communications. They will also verify that measures are in place to prevent unauthorized information transfer.

title: Alternate Communications Paths
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization's information system can maintain its critical functions even in the event of a disruption or failure in its primary communication paths. This is crucial for maintaining system availability and business continuity.
description: This control requires the organization to establish and implement alternate communication paths for its information system to ensure that it remains operational and accessible even if the primary communication paths are compromised or fail.
implementation_guidance: Identify the critical functions of your information system that require continuous availability
Determine the primary communication paths that support these critical functions
Identify potential vulnerabilities or threats that could disrupt these primary communication paths
Establish alternate communication paths that can support the critical functions if the primary paths fail
Implement these alternate paths into your information system
Regularly test the functionality and effectiveness of these alternate paths
Document the alternate communication paths, their implementation, and test results in your System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified its critical functions and their supporting communication paths, established and implemented effective alternate paths, and regularly tests these paths to ensure their functionality.

title: Sensor Relocation
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the integrity of the organization's security monitoring capabilities. It ensures that potential attackers cannot predict or avoid detection by understanding the location and configuration of security sensors.
description: This control requires organizations to periodically relocate intrusion detection and prevention sensors, scanners, and other security-related monitoring devices within the system to make it difficult for potential attackers to identify and evade these security measures.
implementation_guidance: Identify all security sensors and monitoring devices within the system
Develop a schedule for periodically relocating these devices. The schedule should be unpredictable to avoid patterns that could be detected by potential attackers
Implement the relocation schedule, ensuring that each device continues to function effectively after being moved
Document each relocation, including the date, old location, new location, and any changes to the device's configuration
Regularly review and update the relocation schedule as necessary, considering changes to the system and evolving threat landscape
assessment_objectives: Assessors will verify that the organization has a process in place for periodically relocating security sensors and monitoring devices. They will also check that this process is being followed and that relocations are documented.

title: Hardware-enforced Separation and Policy Enforcement
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the system enforces separation of information based on confidentiality and integrity requirements through the use of hardware mechanisms. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent unauthorized access or modification of sensitive data.
description: This control requires the system to use hardware mechanisms to enforce non-bypassable, auditable, and discretely controlled security policies to isolate information based on different levels of confidentiality and integrity.
implementation_guidance: Identify the hardware mechanisms that can be used to enforce separation of information based on confidentiality and integrity requirements
Implement these hardware mechanisms in the system to enforce non-bypassable, auditable, and discretely controlled security policies
Ensure that these hardware mechanisms are configured to isolate information based on different levels of confidentiality and integrity
Regularly review and update these hardware mechanisms to ensure they continue to enforce the required security policies effectively
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that hardware mechanisms are in place to enforce separation of information based on confidentiality and integrity requirements. They will also check that these mechanisms are non-bypassable, auditable, and discretely controlled.

title: Software-enforced Separation and Policy Enforcement
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization's systems are designed and implemented in a way that enforces separation of roles, responsibilities, and data through software mechanisms. This is important for security and compliance as it helps prevent unauthorized access and misuse of information.
description: This control requires the organization to implement software mechanisms that enforce separation of roles, responsibilities, and data. It also requires the enforcement of information flow control policies to prevent unauthorized information transfer within the system.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document the roles and responsibilities within the system that require separation
Define the information flow control policies that need to be enforced within the system
Select and implement software mechanisms that can enforce the identified roles, responsibilities, and information flow control policies
Test the implemented software mechanisms to ensure they are working as intended
Document the implementation details and results of the testing for future reference and audits
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified roles and responsibilities that require separation, defined information flow control policies, and implemented software mechanisms to enforce these. They will also look for documentation of the implementation and testing process.

title: Hardware-based Protection
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the system leverages hardware-based mechanisms to protect its data and operations. This is important for security and compliance as it provides an additional layer of protection, reducing the risk of unauthorized access, alteration, or destruction of information.
description: This control requires the organization to implement hardware-based security mechanisms to protect its system and data. These mechanisms may include, but are not limited to, physical security tokens, smart cards, and hardware security modules (HSMs).
implementation_guidance: Identify the system components that require hardware-based protection. This could include servers, workstations, network devices, etc

Determine the appropriate hardware-based security mechanisms for each component. This could be based on the sensitivity of the data, the criticality of the system operations, or the potential impact of a security breach
Procure and install the chosen hardware-based security mechanisms. This should be done in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions and best practices
Configure the hardware-based security mechanisms to enforce the desired security policies and controls
Test the hardware-based security mechanisms to ensure they are functioning correctly and providing the expected level of protection
Document the implementation of the hardware-based security mechanisms in the System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified system components requiring hardware-based protection, chosen appropriate hardware-based security mechanisms, installed and configured these mechanisms correctly, and documented their implementation in the SSP.
assessment_methods: Compliance will be verified using a combination of methods:

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations establish and implement policies and procedures to manage supply chain risks. This is crucial for security and compliance as it helps prevent unauthorized access, disruption, or damage to the organization's information systems and data.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and disseminate a supply chain risk management policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance. It also requires organizations to establish procedures to facilitate the implementation of the supply chain risk management policy and associated controls.
implementation_guidance: Develop a supply chain risk management policy that includes the purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, and coordination among organizational entities
Document the policy and ensure it is accessible to all relevant personnel
Disseminate the policy to all organizational entities involved in supply chain risk management
Develop procedures that facilitate the implementation of the supply chain risk management policy and associated controls
Implement these procedures and ensure they are followed consistently across the organization
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented supply chain risk management policy and procedures. They will also check that the policy is disseminated and accessible to all relevant personnel, and that the procedures are being followed consistently.

title: Supply Chain Risk Management Plan
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have a comprehensive plan to manage and mitigate risks associated with their supply chain. This is crucial for security and compliance as vulnerabilities in the supply chain can lead to significant security breaches.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and implement a supply chain risk management plan. The plan should address the identification, assessment, and mitigation of risks throughout the system development life cycle.
implementation_guidance: Identify Risks:** Start by identifying potential risks in your supply chain. This could include risks associated with suppliers, products, services, or any other aspect of the supply chain
Assess Risks:** Once risks have been identified, assess them based on their potential impact and likelihood of occurrence. This will help prioritize risk mitigation efforts
Develop Risk Management Plan:** Based on the risk assessment, develop a comprehensive risk management plan. This should include strategies for mitigating each identified risk
Implement Plan:** Implement the risk management plan across the organization. This may involve changes to procurement processes, supplier relationships, or other aspects of the supply chain
Monitor and Update Plan:** Regularly monitor the effectiveness of the risk management plan and update it as necessary based on changes in the supply chain or the risk environment
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for a documented supply chain risk management plan that includes identification, assessment, and mitigation of risks. They will also look for evidence that the plan has been implemented and is regularly monitored and updated.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods:

title: Supply Chain Controls and Processes
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization manages and protects its supply chain from potential threats and vulnerabilities that could compromise the integrity, confidentiality, or availability of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to establish and implement a series of controls and processes to manage and secure its supply chain. This includes identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks throughout the lifecycle of the system, from development and acquisition to disposal.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document all elements of the supply chain, including suppliers, components, and processes
Conduct a risk assessment to identify potential threats and vulnerabilities in the supply chain
Develop and implement controls and processes to mitigate identified risks. This may include supplier vetting, secure handling and storage of components, and secure disposal of system components
Regularly review and update the supply chain risk management plan to address changes in the supply chain or the threat landscape
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a comprehensive understanding of its supply chain and has implemented effective controls and processes to manage and mitigate risks.

title: Provenance
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have a clear understanding of the origin or source of their software, hardware, and firmware components. This is crucial for security and compliance as it helps in identifying and managing potential risks associated with the supply chain, such as counterfeit components or malicious code.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and maintain measures to identify and validate the provenance of all software, hardware, and firmware components in their systems. It also requires organizations to take appropriate actions if the provenance of a component cannot be determined.
implementation_guidance: Develop a policy that outlines the organization's approach to identifying and validating the provenance of all software, hardware, and firmware components
Establish procedures to implement this policy. This may include processes for verifying supplier credentials, checking for authenticity seals, or using trusted distribution channels
Train relevant staff on these procedures and the importance of provenance
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain effective and relevant

Establish a response plan for situations where the provenance of a component cannot be determined. This may include quarantining the component, conducting further investigations, or replacing the component
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy and procedures in place for identifying and validating the provenance of components. They will also look for evidence that these procedures are being followed and that appropriate actions are taken when the provenance of a component cannot be determined.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods. The "examine" method can be used to review the organization's policy, procedures, and records of provenance checks. The "interview" method can be used to confirm that staff understand and follow these procedures. The "test" method can be used to verify that the procedures are effective in identifying and validating the provenance of components.

title: Acquisition Strategies, Tools, and Methods
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have a robust and secure supply chain management system. It is crucial for security and compliance because it helps in mitigating risks associated with the acquisition of systems, components, and services from external suppliers.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and implement strategies, tools, and methods for acquiring information system components and services from suppliers. It also necessitates the organization to ensure that these acquisitions are consistent with its supply chain risk management plan.
implementation_guidance: Develop a comprehensive supply chain risk management plan that outlines the organization's approach to managing risks associated with the acquisition of systems, components, and services

Establish acquisition strategies that align with the risk management plan. This could include selecting trusted suppliers, setting security requirements for suppliers, and implementing contractual protections
Implement tools and methods to support the acquisition strategies. This could include supplier evaluation tools, risk assessment methods, and tracking systems
Regularly review and update the acquisition strategies, tools, and methods to ensure they remain effective and relevant
Train relevant personnel on the acquisition strategies, tools, and methods to ensure they are properly implemented
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has established and implemented acquisition strategies, tools, and methods. They will also check if these are aligned with the organization's supply chain risk management plan.

title: Supplier Assessments and Reviews
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization's suppliers meet the necessary security requirements. This is important for security and compliance because suppliers often have access to sensitive information and systems. If a supplier's security is compromised, it could lead to a breach in the organization's own security.
description: This control requires organizations to regularly assess and review their suppliers. This includes evaluating the supplier's ability to meet security requirements and taking appropriate action based on the results of the assessment.
implementation_guidance: Identify all suppliers that have access to sensitive information or systems
Develop a standardized assessment process to evaluate each supplier's security controls and practices
Conduct regular assessments of each supplier using the standardized process
Review the results of each assessment and determine whether the supplier meets the organization's security requirements

Take appropriate action based on the results of the assessment. This could include working with the supplier to improve their security, finding a new supplier, or implementing additional controls to mitigate the risk
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a process in place for regularly assessing and reviewing suppliers. They will also look for evidence that the organization takes appropriate action based on the results of these assessments.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods. Assessors may examine documentation of the assessment process and results, interview staff involved in the process, and test the effectiveness of the actions taken based on the assessment results.

title: Supply Chain Operations Security
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that an organization's supply chain operations are secure and that the organization is aware of and managing the risks associated with its supply chain. This is important for security and compliance as vulnerabilities in the supply chain can lead to breaches in the organization's security.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and implement measures to identify, assess, manage, and monitor supply chain risks throughout the system development life cycle. This includes ensuring the integrity, security, resilience, and quality of products and services acquired from suppliers.
implementation_guidance: Identify and Document Supply Chain Risks:** Begin by identifying potential risks in your supply chain. This could include risks related to supplier reliability, product quality, or security vulnerabilities. Document these risks for future reference
Assess Risks:** Evaluate the potential impact of each identified risk. This should take into account both the likelihood of the risk occurring and the potential damage it could cause
Develop Risk Management Strategies:** For each identified risk, develop a strategy to manage it. This could involve mitigating the risk, transferring it, accepting it, or avoiding it

Implement Risk Management Strategies:** Put your risk management strategies into action. This could involve changing suppliers, implementing additional security measures, or developing contingency plans
Monitor and Review:** Regularly monitor your supply chain to ensure that your risk management strategies are effective. Review and update your strategies as necessary
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified and assessed its supply chain risks, developed and implemented risk management strategies, and is regularly monitoring and reviewing its supply chain security.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods. The "Examine" method may involve reviewing the organization's documented supply chain risks and risk management strategies. The "Interview" method may involve discussions with key personnel responsible for supply chain management. The "Test" method may involve evaluating the effectiveness of the organization's risk management strategies and its monitoring and review processes.

title: Notification Agreements
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have formal agreements in place with their suppliers to notify them of any changes that could affect the supply chain's security. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to mitigate risks associated with supply chain disruptions, such as those caused by cyber threats or natural disasters.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and maintain agreements with suppliers that mandate the notification of changes affecting the supply chain. These changes could include, but are not limited to, changes in the supplier's organizational structure, financial status, or security practices.
implementation_guidance: Identify all suppliers that are part of your organization's supply chain

Establish formal agreements with each supplier. These agreements should include clauses that require the supplier to notify your organization of any significant changes that could affect the supply chain
Define what constitutes a significant change. This could include changes in the supplier's organizational structure, financial status, or security practices

Implement a process for receiving and responding to notifications from suppliers. This process should include steps for assessing the potential impact of the change on your organization's security and taking appropriate action
Regularly review and update the agreements as necessary to ensure they remain effective and relevant
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that formal agreements are in place with suppliers and that these agreements include notification clauses. They will also look for evidence that the organization has a process for receiving and responding to notifications from suppliers.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of examination and interview methods. The assessor will examine the agreements to confirm that they include notification clauses. They will also interview personnel to verify that a process is in place for receiving and responding to notifications, and that this process is being followed.

title: Tamper Resistance and Detection
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the integrity of system components by ensuring that any unauthorized physical alterations, tampering, or damage to the system components are detected and resisted. This is crucial for maintaining the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to incorporate tamper-resistant and tamper-detecting features into the system. This includes mechanisms to prevent unauthorized physical access, alteration, or damage to the system, and to alert the organization if such events occur.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document all system components that require tamper resistance and detection
Determine the appropriate tamper-resistant and tamper-detection features for each component. This could include physical locks, seals, or alarms, as well as software-based intrusion detection systems
Implement the chosen features, ensuring they are properly configured and activated
Test the features to confirm they function as expected, and adjust as necessary
Train staff to respond appropriately to tamper alerts
Regularly review and update the tamper resistance and detection measures as needed
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that tamper-resistant and tamper-detection features have been implemented and are functioning correctly. They will also check that the organization has procedures in place to respond to tamper alerts.

title: Inspection of Systems or Components
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations inspect systems, system components, and information system services for potential supply chain risks, tampering, or counterfeit items. This is crucial for maintaining the integrity and security of the organization's information systems and preventing potential vulnerabilities or attacks.
description: This control requires organizations to inspect systems, system components, and information system services from suppliers prior to installation. The inspection should be aimed at identifying and managing potential supply chain risks, including tampering and counterfeit items.
implementation_guidance: Identify and Document:** Identify all systems, system components, and information system services that are sourced from suppliers. Document these items along with their respective suppliers

Develop Inspection Procedures:** Develop standard procedures for inspecting the identified items. These procedures should be designed to detect tampering, counterfeit items, and other supply chain risks
Train Personnel:** Train relevant personnel on the inspection procedures. Ensure they understand what to look for and how to document their findings
Perform Inspections:** Inspect all incoming items from suppliers prior to installation. Document the results of each inspection

Manage Identified Risks:** If any risks are identified during the inspection, take appropriate action to manage these risks. This could include rejecting the item, working with the supplier to resolve the issue, or implementing additional controls to mitigate the risk
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all systems, system components, and information system services from suppliers, developed and implemented inspection procedures, trained personnel on these procedures, performed inspections, and managed any identified risks.

title: Component Authenticity
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure the authenticity of system components. It is crucial for security and compliance as it helps prevent the introduction of counterfeit or tampered components into the system, which could compromise system integrity, confidentiality, or availability.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and maintain measures to identify and manage the risks associated with the authenticity of system components throughout the system development life cycle.
implementation_guidance: Develop a policy and procedure to verify the authenticity of system components. This should include a process for identifying and managing risks associated with counterfeit and tampered components

Implement a system to track and manage components throughout their lifecycle, from procurement to disposal. This could involve maintaining a database of component information, including supplier details, purchase dates, and any authenticity checks performed

Establish relationships with trusted suppliers and ensure they follow appropriate security practices. This could include conducting audits or requiring suppliers to provide evidence of their security practices
Regularly review and update the authenticity verification process to ensure it remains effective as new risks emerge
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a policy and procedure in place for verifying component authenticity, that this policy is being followed, and that it is effective in managing the risks associated with counterfeit and tampered components.

title: Component Disposal
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that system components are disposed of in a manner that protects the system and its data from unauthorized access. This is important for security and compliance as it prevents potential data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive information.
description: This control requires organizations to establish and implement procedures for the secure disposal or sanitization of system components. The procedures should ensure that the information system, system component, or information system service is disposed of or sanitized using approved procedures to prevent unauthorized individuals from gaining access.
implementation_guidance: Develop and document procedures for secure disposal or sanitization of system components. These procedures should include steps for identifying, tracking, and securing components prior to disposal
Train relevant personnel on the procedures and the importance of secure disposal
Implement the procedures consistently when disposing of or sanitizing system components
Regularly review and update the procedures as necessary to address changes in technology, threats, or other relevant factors
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for documented procedures for secure disposal or sanitization of system components. They will also look for evidence that these procedures are being followed and that relevant personnel have been trained on them.

title: Policy and Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have established and documented policies and procedures for system and information integrity. This is crucial for security and compliance as it provides a structured approach to prevent, detect, and correct information flaws that could compromise system integrity or lead to data breaches.
description: This control requires organizations to develop, document, and disseminate a system and information integrity policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance. It also requires procedures to facilitate the implementation of the system and information integrity policy and associated system and information integrity controls.
implementation_guidance: Develop a comprehensive system and information integrity policy, clearly defining the purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, management commitment, coordination among organizational entities, and compliance requirements
Document the policy and ensure it is easily accessible to all relevant personnel
Develop procedures that facilitate the implementation of the system and information integrity policy and associated controls. These procedures should be detailed and actionable
Disseminate the policy and procedures to all relevant personnel, ensuring they understand and are trained on the requirements
Regularly review and update the policy and procedures to ensure they remain relevant and effective
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence of a well-documented and disseminated system and information integrity policy and procedures. They will also evaluate whether the policy and procedures are being effectively implemented and followed within the organization.

title: Flaw Remediation
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the organization identifies, reports, and corrects information system flaws in a timely manner. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent potential exploitation of vulnerabilities that could compromise the system's confidentiality, integrity, or availability.
description: This control requires the organization to identify and remediate system flaws, test software and firmware updates related to flaw remediation for effectiveness, and install security-relevant software and firmware updates.
implementation_guidance: Establish a process for flaw identification: This could involve using automated tools to scan for vulnerabilities, subscribing to alert services for vulnerability announcements, or conducting regular system audits
Once flaws are identified, prioritize them based on risk level: High-risk flaws should be addressed immediately, while lower-risk flaws can be scheduled for future remediation
Develop and test patches or fixes for identified flaws: Ensure that these patches do not introduce new vulnerabilities into the system
Apply the patches or fixes to the system: This should be done in a controlled manner, with back-out plans in place in case the update causes issues
Document all actions taken during the flaw remediation process: This includes the identification, prioritization, and remediation steps, as well as any testing conducted
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a process in place for flaw identification and remediation, that this process is followed consistently, and that all actions are documented. They will also verify that patches and updates are tested before being applied to the system.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods. The "examine" method could involve reviewing the organization's policies and procedures for flaw remediation, as well as documentation of actions taken. The "interview" method could involve discussions with staff responsible for flaw identification and remediation. The "test" method could involve a review of the system to verify that patches and updates have been applied correctly.

title: Malicious Code Protection
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the integrity of the system and its data by preventing, detecting, and removing malicious code. It is crucial for security and compliance as it helps to prevent unauthorized access, data breaches, and system disruptions that can be caused by malicious code.
description: This control requires the organization to implement mechanisms for malicious code protection at information system entry and exit points, including email attachments, web accesses, and portable and mobile devices. It also requires regular updates of malicious code protection mechanisms and periodic scans for malicious code.
implementation_guidance: Identify all information system entry and exit points that need protection, such as email servers, web servers, and user endpoints
Implement malicious code protection mechanisms at these points. This could include antivirus software, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and web application firewalls
Configure these mechanisms to perform real-time scans of files from external sources as the files are downloaded, opened, or executed
Regularly update the malicious code protection mechanisms to ensure they can detect and protect against the latest threats
Perform periodic scans for malicious code in the information system, including all connected devices
Establish procedures for responding to detected malicious code, including isolating affected systems, removing the malicious code, and reporting the incident
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that malicious code protection mechanisms are in place at all necessary points, that these mechanisms are regularly updated, and that periodic scans are performed. They will also look for evidence of procedures for responding to detected malicious code.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods:

title: System Monitoring
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations are actively monitoring their information systems to detect unauthorized activities and potential security incidents. This is crucial for maintaining the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of the system and its data.
description: This control requires organizations to monitor their information systems on an ongoing basis for unusual or unauthorized activities. This includes monitoring inbound and outbound communications traffic, as well as system vulnerabilities. The organization must also alert appropriate personnel when potential security incidents are detected.
implementation_guidance: Develop a system monitoring plan that details what will be monitored, how often, and who will be responsible for monitoring activities
Implement monitoring tools and technologies that can effectively track and analyze system activities
Regularly review and analyze system logs and alerts to identify potential security incidents
Establish a process for responding to detected security incidents, including escalation procedures and incident reporting mechanisms
Train relevant personnel on their roles and responsibilities related to system monitoring and incident response
Regularly update and refine the system monitoring plan and tools based on lessons learned from previous incidents and changes in the system or threat landscape
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a comprehensive system monitoring plan in place and that it is being effectively implemented. They will also evaluate the organization's ability to detect and respond to potential security incidents.

title: Security Alerts, Advisories, and Directives
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations are aware of and respond to information system flaws, vulnerabilities, and threats in a timely manner. It helps maintain the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of the system and its data.
description: This control requires organizations to receive, analyze, and respond to security alerts, advisories, and directives from external organizations and sources. It also requires organizations to issue alerts, advisories, and directives to appropriate personnel within the organization.
implementation_guidance: Establish a process for receiving security alerts, advisories, and directives from trusted external sources, such as US-CERT, vendors, or industry-specific information sharing and analysis centers (ISACs)
Assign responsibility to specific personnel or teams for analyzing and responding to these alerts, advisories, and directives
Develop procedures for disseminating security alerts, advisories, and directives within the organization to relevant personnel
Implement a system for tracking the organization's response to each alert, advisory, or directive, including any actions taken to address identified vulnerabilities or threats
Regularly review and update the organization's processes and procedures for handling security alerts, advisories, and directives to ensure they remain effective and efficient
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a process in place for receiving, analyzing, and responding to security alerts, advisories, and directives. They will also look for evidence that the organization disseminates these alerts, advisories, and directives to appropriate personnel and tracks its response to them.

title: Security and Privacy Function Verification
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the security and privacy functions of an information system are performing as intended. This is important for security and compliance as it helps to prevent, detect, and correct security and privacy-related anomalies and incidents.
description: This control requires organizations to verify the correct operation of security and privacy functions periodically and upon system startup, restart, shutdown, or at a defined frequency. It also requires organizations to notify appropriate officials in case of a failure of security or privacy functions.
implementation_guidance: Identify Security and Privacy Functions:** Identify all the security and privacy functions of your information system. This could include access controls, encryption, intrusion detection systems, etc
Define Verification Procedures:** Develop procedures to verify the correct operation of these functions. This could involve system checks, audits, or other verification methods
Schedule Verification:** Schedule these verifications to occur at system startup, restart, shutdown, or at a defined frequency
Implement Notification Procedures:** Establish procedures to notify appropriate officials in case of a failure of security or privacy functions
Document Procedures:** Document all these procedures in your System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified its security and privacy functions, developed and implemented verification procedures, scheduled regular verifications, and established notification procedures for function failures.

title: Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure the integrity of software, firmware, and information by detecting and protecting against unauthorized changes. This is critical for maintaining the security and reliability of the system.
description: This control requires organizations to employ integrity verification tools to check for unauthorized changes to software, firmware, and information. It also mandates the organization to take action when such changes are detected.
implementation_guidance: Identify all software, firmware, and information that are critical to the system's operation
Implement integrity verification tools to regularly check for unauthorized changes. These tools could include checksums, cryptographic hashes, or digital signatures
Establish procedures for responding to detected unauthorized changes. This could include isolating affected components, restoring from a known good state, and investigating the source of the change
Document the procedures and tools used for integrity verification in the System Security Plan
Train relevant personnel on the procedures for verifying integrity and responding to unauthorized changes
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that integrity verification tools are in place and regularly used. They will also look for documented procedures for responding to detected unauthorized changes and evidence that these procedures are followed.

title: Spam Protection
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the organization's information systems from the potential threats posed by spam, such as phishing attacks, malware, and the loss of system performance. It is important for security and compliance as it helps to maintain the integrity and availability of the system and its data.
description: This control requires organizations to employ spam protection mechanisms at information system entry and exit points to detect and take action on unsolicited messages.
implementation_guidance: Identify all information system entry and exit points that need protection from spam. This could include email servers, web servers, and other communication interfaces
Select and implement spam protection mechanisms. These could include spam filters, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, and anti-malware software
Configure the spam protection mechanisms to detect and take action on unsolicited messages. Actions could include blocking, quarantining, or marking messages as spam
Regularly update and maintain the spam protection mechanisms to ensure they are effective against the latest spam threats
Train users on how to recognize and handle spam, as well as the importance of not opening suspicious emails or clicking on unknown links
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that spam protection mechanisms are in place at all necessary entry and exit points, that these mechanisms are properly configured and maintained, and that users are trained on spam recognition and handling.

title: Information Input Restrictions
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized, unauthenticated, or unintended data input into the system, which could lead to data corruption, system instability, or security breaches. It is crucial for maintaining the integrity and security of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to define and implement restrictions on the information input into the system. It involves validating the data input, enforcing input restrictions, and rejecting, sanitizing, or correcting any input that does not meet the defined criteria.
implementation_guidance: Identify all points of data input into the system, including user interfaces, APIs, and data imports
Define the acceptable criteria for each input point, considering the type, format, length, and range of the data

Implement mechanisms to validate the data input against the defined criteria. This could involve input validation techniques such as whitelisting, blacklisting, regular expressions, and data type checks
Implement mechanisms to enforce the input restrictions, such as disabling certain input methods, limiting the size of the input, or requiring specific formats
Implement mechanisms to handle any input that does not meet the criteria, such as rejecting the input, sanitizing it, or correcting it
Regularly review and update the input restrictions and validation mechanisms as needed
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all points of data input, defined acceptable criteria for each input point, implemented mechanisms to validate and enforce the input restrictions, and handles non-compliant input appropriately.

title: Information Input Validation
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the system is protected from incorrect or maliciously crafted input data. This is important for security and compliance because invalid input can lead to a variety of security vulnerabilities, including SQL injection, cross-site scripting, and buffer overflow attacks.
description: This control requires the organization to check the validity of information input to the system. This includes checking for appropriate data types, data length, data syntax, and numerical ranges.
implementation_guidance: Identify Input Sources:** Identify all sources of input to the system. This could include user interfaces, APIs, and data feeds
Define Input Validation Rules:** Define rules for what constitutes valid input for each source. This should include checks for data type, length, syntax, and numerical range
Implement Input Validation:** Implement these rules in the system. This could be done in the application code or using a security framework or library that provides input validation functionality
Test Input Validation:** Test the input validation functionality to ensure it is working as expected. This should include testing with both valid and invalid input

Monitor and Respond to Input Validation Errors:** Monitor the system for input validation errors and respond appropriately when they occur. This could include logging the error, alerting an administrator, or blocking the source of the invalid input
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all sources of input to the system, defined and implemented input validation rules, tested the input validation functionality, and has a process in place to monitor and respond to input validation errors.
assessment_methods: Compliance will be verified through a combination of methods. The "examine" method will involve reviewing the input validation rules and the code or configuration that implements them. The "interview" method will involve discussing the input validation process with the individuals responsible for implementing and maintaining it. The "test" method will involve attempting to input invalid data into the system to see if it is correctly identified and handled.

title: Error Handling
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent potential exploitation of system errors by malicious actors. By effectively managing and concealing error messages, organizations can prevent the disclosure of information that could be used to compromise the system.
description: This control requires that the information system identifies and handles errors in a manner that prevents the disclosure of exploitable information. It also requires the system to generate error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing sensitive or potentially harmful information.
implementation_guidance: Identify Error Types:** Start by identifying the different types of errors that your system may encounter. This could include system errors, user errors, or data errors
Develop Error Handling Procedures:** For each type of error, develop a procedure for handling the error. This should include steps to identify the error, isolate the error, and correct the error

Design Error Messages:** Design error messages that provide enough information for users or administrators to correct the error, but do not reveal sensitive system information or information that could be exploited by an attacker
Implement Error Handling Procedures:** Implement the error handling procedures and error messages in your system
Test Error Handling Procedures:** Test your error handling procedures to ensure they work as expected and do not reveal sensitive information
Monitor and Review:** Regularly monitor and review your error handling procedures to ensure they continue to protect your system
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified potential system errors, developed and implemented error handling procedures, and designed error messages that do not reveal sensitive information. They will also look for evidence that the organization regularly reviews and updates these procedures.
assessment_methods: Compliance can be verified through a combination of methods:

title: Information Management and Retention
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that organizations have effective measures in place for managing and retaining information throughout its lifecycle. This is crucial for maintaining the integrity of the system and ensuring compliance with legal, regulatory, and operational requirements.
description: This control requires organizations to create, protect, and retain information system audit records to enable the monitoring, analysis, investigation, and reporting of unlawful, unauthorized, or inappropriate information system activity.
implementation_guidance: Develop and document a policy for information management and retention that aligns with legal, regulatory, and operational requirements
Identify the types of information that need to be retained, including system logs, audit records, and other relevant data
Determine the appropriate retention periods for each type of information based on its relevance and usefulness
Implement mechanisms for securely storing and protecting the retained information
Regularly review and update the information management and retention policy to ensure it remains effective and compliant with evolving requirements
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has a documented policy for information management and retention, that the policy is being effectively implemented, and that the retained information is being securely stored and protected.

title: Predictable Failure Prevention
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent predictable system failures that could compromise the security of the information system and the data it processes, stores, and transmits. This is important for maintaining the integrity, availability, and confidentiality of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to monitor system components for signs of impending failure and take appropriate action to prevent the failure and mitigate the impact. This includes monitoring for unusual or excessive consumption of system resources that may indicate a potential system failure.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document critical system components that, if they fail, could impact the security of the system
Implement monitoring tools and procedures to detect signs of potential failure in these critical components
Establish thresholds for system resource consumption that, if exceeded, trigger alerts
Develop and implement procedures for responding to alerts, including steps to prevent the failure and mitigate its impact
Regularly review and update the monitoring tools, procedures, and thresholds to ensure they remain effective as the system and its environment evolve
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified critical system components, implemented effective monitoring, established appropriate thresholds, and developed procedures for responding to alerts. They will also look for evidence that the organization regularly reviews and updates these measures.

title: Non-persistence
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent malicious code from persisting in a system and to limit the potential damage from malicious code. It is important for security and compliance as it helps to maintain the integrity of the system and the information it processes.
description: This control requires organizations to implement non-persistent and/or execution-only storage spaces to prevent the persistence of malicious code. It also requires organizations to refresh or reboot the system periodically to clear out any potential malicious code.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document the system components that require non-persistent storage spaces

Implement non-persistent storage spaces or execution-only spaces in the identified system components. This could involve configuring the system to use RAM disks or other forms of volatile memory for temporary storage

Develop and implement a schedule for refreshing or rebooting the system to clear out potential malicious code. The frequency of refreshes or reboots should be based on the risk level and operational requirements of the system
Document the implementation of the non-persistent storage spaces and the refresh/reboot schedule in the System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that non-persistent storage spaces or execution-only spaces have been implemented in the system. They will also look for a documented schedule for system refreshes or reboots.

title: Information Output Filtering
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized or harmful data from being transmitted from the system, thereby protecting the integrity and confidentiality of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to implement information output filtering mechanisms at the application and/or operating system level to prevent unauthorized or harmful data from being transmitted from the system.
implementation_guidance: Identify the types of information that should not be transmitted from the system. This could include sensitive data, malware, or other harmful content
Determine the appropriate filtering mechanisms to prevent this information from being transmitted. This could include application-level filters, operating system-level filters, or both
Implement the chosen filtering mechanisms. This may involve configuring existing software or hardware, or installing new software or hardware
Test the filtering mechanisms to ensure they are working as expected. This could involve attempting to transmit prohibited information and verifying that it is blocked
Document the implementation of the filtering mechanisms in the System Security Plan (SSP)
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified prohibited information, implemented appropriate filtering mechanisms, tested these mechanisms, and documented their implementation in the SSP.

title: Memory Protection
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized code execution, data leakage, and system crashes by protecting the system's memory. It is crucial for security and compliance as it safeguards the system from potential threats and vulnerabilities that can compromise the integrity of the system and its data.
description: This control requires the organization to implement security measures that protect the system's memory from unauthorized access and manipulation. It involves the use of techniques such as address space layout randomization and data execution prevention to prevent unauthorized code execution.
implementation_guidance: Identify and document all system components that require memory protection
Implement memory protection techniques such as address space layout randomization (ASLR) and data execution prevention (DEP) on the identified system components
Configure the system to ensure that memory protection measures are always active and cannot be bypassed or deactivated without proper authorization
Regularly update and patch the system to ensure that the memory protection measures are up-to-date and effective against the latest threats
Train staff on the importance of memory protection and how to maintain it
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that memory protection measures have been implemented and are actively maintained. They will also check that the organization has procedures in place to ensure that these measures are updated and patched regularly.

title: Fail-safe Procedures
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that the system remains secure even in the event of a failure. It is important for security and compliance because it helps to prevent unauthorized access or damage to the system when normal protective measures fail.
description: This control requires the organization to establish and maintain fail-safe procedures that protect the system in case of operational failure. These procedures should ensure that the system defaults to a secure state that minimizes potential damage or unauthorized access.
implementation_guidance: Identify potential points of failure within the system
For each identified point of failure, define a secure state that the system should default to in the event of a failure
Develop procedures that will guide the system to the defined secure state when a failure occurs

title: Personally Identifiable Information Quality Operations
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that PII is processed, stored, and transmitted in a manner that protects its confidentiality, integrity, and availability. It is crucial for security and compliance because mishandling of PII can lead to breaches of privacy, identity theft, and non-compliance with laws and regulations.
description: This control requires organizations to implement measures to ensure the quality and integrity of PII during its lifecycle. It also requires organizations to provide clear notice to individuals regarding the purpose and methods of PII processing, as well as any third-party sharing.
implementation_guidance: Identify all systems that process, store, or transmit PII
Develop and implement policies and procedures to ensure the quality and integrity of PII. This could include data validation checks, access controls, and encryption for data at rest and in transit
Provide clear notice to individuals about the purpose of PII collection, how it will be processed, and any third-party sharing. This could be done through privacy notices or consent forms
Regularly review and update policies and procedures to reflect changes in laws, regulations, or business practices
Train staff on PII handling procedures and the importance of PII protection
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented measures to ensure the quality and integrity of PII. They will also look for evidence that individuals are provided with clear notice about PII processing.

title: De-identification
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the privacy of individuals by ensuring that personally identifiable information (PII) is not inadvertently disclosed. This is important for security and compliance because it helps prevent unauthorized access to sensitive information, which could lead to identity theft or other forms of harm.
description: This control requires organizations to implement procedures for de-identifying PII, which involves removing or obscuring any information that could be used to identify an individual. This includes, but is not limited to, names, social security numbers, and addresses.
implementation_guidance: Identify all systems and processes that handle PII
Develop and document procedures for de-identifying PII. This could involve techniques such as data masking, pseudonymization, or anonymization
Implement these procedures in all relevant systems and processes
Train staff on the importance of de-identification and how to follow the procedures
Regularly review and update the de-identification procedures as necessary, especially when new types of PII are introduced or when systems and processes are updated
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented procedures for de-identifying PII and that these procedures are being followed. They will also look for evidence that the procedures are effective at preventing the disclosure of PII.

title: Tainting
purpose: The purpose of this control is to prevent unauthorized data from influencing the execution of organizational processes. It is important for security and compliance as it helps to maintain the integrity of the system and its data, thereby reducing the risk of data breaches and other security incidents.
description: This control requires organizations to implement mechanisms that identify and manage tainted information. Tainted information is data that has been received from untrusted sources or has been altered by an unauthorized entity. The mechanisms should prevent this information from influencing the execution of organizational processes.
implementation_guidance: Identify all sources of data that the organization's systems process
Classify these sources based on their trustworthiness
Implement mechanisms that can identify and manage tainted information. This could involve using data validation techniques, such as input validation, output encoding, and data sanitization
Configure these mechanisms to prevent tainted information from influencing the execution of organizational processes
Regularly review and update the mechanisms as necessary to ensure they remain effective
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has implemented mechanisms to identify and manage tainted information. They will also check that these mechanisms are configured to prevent tainted information from influencing the execution of organizational processes.

title: Information Refresh
purpose: The purpose of this control is to ensure that information is updated and refreshed in a timely manner to maintain its accuracy, completeness, and usefulness. This is important for security and compliance as outdated or inaccurate information can lead to poor decision-making, increased vulnerabilities, and non-compliance with regulations.
description: This control requires organizations to refresh information system output to ensure that it accurately reflects the current state of the system. This includes updating, replacing, or purging information as necessary.
implementation_guidance: Identify the types of information that require regular refreshing. This can include system logs, status reports, and other system output
Determine the frequency at which each type of information should be refreshed based on its nature and the organization's needs
Develop and implement procedures for refreshing the identified information at the determined frequency
Establish a process to review and verify the accuracy of refreshed information
Document the procedures and processes in the System Security Plan
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified the information that requires refreshing, determined appropriate refresh frequencies, and implemented procedures for refreshing information. They will also look for evidence that the organization reviews and verifies the accuracy of refreshed information.

title: Information Diversity
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the integrity of the system and its information by ensuring diversity in the sources of its information. This is important for security and compliance as it reduces the risk of a single point of failure or compromise.
description: This control requires the organization to use diverse information sources to address the risk of a single point of failure or compromise. The organization must ensure that the system is not overly dependent on a single source of information.
implementation_guidance: Identify all sources of information that the system relies on
Evaluate the criticality of each information source to the system's operation
Identify alternative sources of information for each critical source identified
Implement mechanisms to switch to alternative sources in case of failure or compromise of the primary source
Regularly review and update the information diversity strategy to account for changes in the system or its environment
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified all sources of information, evaluated their criticality, identified alternative sources, and implemented mechanisms to switch to these alternatives. They will also look for evidence of regular reviews and updates to the information diversity strategy.

title: Information Fragmentation
purpose: The purpose of this control is to protect the integrity and confidentiality of information during transmission. By fragmenting information, the risk of interception and reconstruction of data by unauthorized individuals is reduced.
description: This control requires organizations to implement information fragmentation where the capability exists. This means breaking down information into smaller, non-usable parts during transmission, making it more difficult for unauthorized individuals to intercept and understand the data.
implementation_guidance: Identify the systems and processes where information fragmentation can be implemented. This could include data transmission processes, data storage, and other areas where sensitive information is handled
Develop a plan for implementing information fragmentation. This should include the technical requirements, resources needed, and a timeline for implementation
Implement the information fragmentation process. This could involve configuring systems to automatically fragment data during transmission, or implementing manual processes where necessary
Monitor the effectiveness of the information fragmentation process. This should include regular checks to ensure the process is working as intended and updates as necessary to maintain effectiveness
assessment_objectives: Assessors will look for evidence that the organization has identified where information fragmentation can be implemented, developed and implemented a plan for information fragmentation, and is monitoring the effectiveness of the process.
